chapter.summary: Covers the management of children with a life-limiting condition.

topic.topicName: End of life care in children

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What general principles should I be aware of when managing the end of life care needs of children?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Children with a life-limiting condition should be cared for by a defined multidisciplinary team, and have a named medical specialist who leads on and coordinates their care. Depending on the needs of the child, this may include:
    • Healthcare professionals from primary, secondary or tertiary services, including specialists in the child's underlying life-limiting condition, hospice professionals and members of the specialist palliative care team.
    • Social care practitioners.
    • Educational professionals.
    • Allied health professionals (for example physiotherapists, occupational therapists, and psychological therapists). 
  • Every family should receive a child and family centred multidisciplinary and multi-agency assessment of their needs as soon as possible after diagnosis or recognition of a life-limiting condition — this should include the whole family including parents, siblings, grandparents and others identified by the child. 
  • The assessment should be reviewed at appropriate intervals and include:  
    • Details of the professionals and services involved with the family.
    • Medical information.
    • Functional abilities of the child.
    • Nursing and personal care needs.
    • Emotional needs.
    • Educational needs.
    • The family’s home circumstances.
  • Recognize that children and young people with life-limiting conditions and their parents or carers have a central role in decision-making and care planning. 
    • Discuss and regularly review how they want to be involved in making decisions about their care, because this varies between individuals, at different times, and depending on what decisions are being made.
      • In all discussions with children and young people and their parents or carers explore with them whether, based on their beliefs and values, there are any aspects of care about which they have particular views or feelings.
    • Explain that their contribution to decisions about their care is very important, but that they do not have to make decisions alone and the multidisciplinary team will be involved as well.
    • Give them enough time and opportunities for discussions when difficult decisions must be made about end of life care.
  • Use parallel planning when developing care plans to take account of possible unpredictability in the course of the condition.
  • Think about how to provide information, taking into account the child's age and level of understanding.
    • When appropriate, use formats such as:
      • One-to-one discussion.
      • Play, art and music activities.
      • Written materials and pictures.
      • Digital media, for example social media.
    • Focus on their views and take account of:
      • Their personal and family situation.
      • Their beliefs and values.
      • Any special needs, such as communication aids or the need for interpreters.
  • Think about how best to communicate with each child and their parents or carers:
    • When the life-limiting condition is first recognized. 
    • When reviewing and developing the advance care plan. 
    • If their condition worsens.
    • When they are approaching the end of life.
  • Ask children and their parents or carers if there are other people important to them (such as friends, boyfriends or girlfriends, teachers, or foster parents) who they would like to be involved, and if so how they would like those people to provide a supporting role.
  • Ask how children and their parents or carers would like to discuss the life-limiting condition. For example:
    • Ask which topics they feel are important and would particularly want information on.
    • Ask whether there are topics they do not want detailed information on and discuss their concerns.
    • If appropriate, ask parents or carers whether they think their child understands their condition and its management, and which professional their child would like to talk to about it.
    • If appropriate, ask parents or carers what they think their child should be told about their condition.
    • Discuss with the child or young person and their parents or carers their right to confidentiality and how information about their condition will be shared.
    • Review these issues with them regularly, because their feelings and circumstances may change over time, and they may need different information at different times.
  • When talking to children and their parents or carers:
    • Be sensitive, honest and realistic.
    • Give reassurance when appropriate.
    • Discuss any uncertainties about the condition and treatment.
  • Be alert for signs or situations that the child, or their parents or carers need more information or discussions, for example, if:
    • They are more anxious or concerned.
    • The child or young person's condition deteriorates.
    • A significant change to the treatment plan is needed.
  • Provide children and their parents or carers with appropriate information and advice.
  • Manage transition from children's to adults' services (where appropriate) in line with the NICE guideline Transition from children’s to adults’ services for young people using health or social care services.
  • Be aware that:
    • Continuity of care is important — if possible, avoid frequent changes to the healthcare professionals caring for them.
    • Siblings will need support (this may include social, practical, psychological and spiritual support) to cope with:
      • The effects of their parents' or carers' grieving.
      • Their brother's or sister's condition and death. 
    • Other family members (for example grandparents) and people important to the child or young person (for example friends, boyfriends or girlfriends) may also need support.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline End of life care for infants, children and young people with life-limiting conditions: planning and management [NICE, 2019], and the charity Together for Short Lives document A core care pathway for children with life-limiting and life-threatening conditions [TSL, 2013]. 

  • The recommendation that a multidisciplinary and multi-agency child and family needs assessment should be completed as soon as possible after diagnosis or recognition of a life-limiting condition is based on the Together for Short Lives document A core care pathway for children with life-limiting and life-threatening conditions [TSL, 2013].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage advance care planning?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• All children with life-limiting conditions should have an advance care plan in their medical record. 
    • This should not be confused with a 'do not attempt resuscitation' order. 
  • Develop an advanced care plan at an appropriate time for the current and future care of each child with a life-limiting condition, taking into account the beliefs and values of the child and their parents or carers. The advance care plan should include:
    • Demographic information about the child or young person and their family. 
    • Up-to-date contact information for:
      • The child or young person's parents or carers.
      • The key professionals involved in care.
    • A statement about who has responsibility for giving consent.
    • A summary of the life-limiting condition.
    • An agreed approach to communicating with and providing information to the child or young person and their parents or carers.
    • An outline of the child or young person's life ambitions and wishes, for example on:
      • Family and other relationships.
      • Social activities and participation.
      • Education.
      • How to incorporate their religious, spiritual, and cultural beliefs and values into their care.
    • A record of significant discussions with the child or young person and their parents or carers, including any discussions and decisions that have taken place on:
      • The preferred place of care and place of death. 
      • Organ and tissue donation. 
      • Management of life-threatening events, including plans for resuscitation or life support.
    • Agreed treatment plans and objectives.
    • Education plans, if relevant.
    • Specific wishes, for example on funeral arrangements and care of the body. 
    • A distribution list for the advance care plan.
  • When making an advance care plan, discuss with the child or young person and their parents or carers:
    • The nature of the life-limiting condition, its likely consequences, and its prognosis.
    • The expected benefits and possible harms of the management options.
  • Begin discussing an advance care plan with parents during the pregnancy if there is an antenatal diagnosis of a life-limiting condition.
  • Explain to children and their parents or carers that advance care planning should:
    • Help them be involved in planning their care and give them time to think about their views carefully.
    • Help them to understand the life-limiting condition and its management. 
    • Help to prepare for possible future difficulties or complications.
    • Support continuity of care — for example, if there are changes in the professionals involved or in the care setting (such as a hospital admission or discharge).
  • Share the advance care plan with the child and their parents or carers, and think about which professionals and services involved in the individual child or young person's care should also see it.
  • Regularly review advance care plans:
    • With relevant members of the multidisciplinary team.
    • In discussion with the child and their parents or carers.
  • Update the advance care plan when needed, discuss the changes with the child and their parents (or carers), and share it with everyone involved after each update. For example if:
    • New professionals become involved.
    • The care setting changes (for example hospital admission or discharge) the child or young person and their parents or carers move home.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Organ and tissue donation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Talk to the child and their parents or carers about organ or tissue donation, and explore their views and feelings.
    • Explain which organs or tissues (if any) it may be possible to donate.
  • Involve the organ donation service if needed — if organ or tissue donation is not possible, explain why.
  • If the child is eligible to donate organs or tissue, ask them if they and their parents or carers would like to discuss this, and if so:
    • Provide written information if needed.
    • Discuss how deciding to donate could affect their care, for example by changing their place of care and place of death.
    • Explain the practical policies and procedures involved.
  • If the child does not have the capacity to decide about organ and tissue donation, ask their parents or carers to make the decision.

subChapters.fullItemName: Preferred place of care and death
subChapters.htmlHeader: Preferred place of care and place of death
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Discuss with children with life-limiting conditions and their parents (or carers) where they would prefer to be cared for and where they would prefer to die.
  • Agree the preferred place of care and place of death, taking into account:
    • Their wishes, which are personal and individual.
    • Their religious, spiritual and cultural values.
    • The views of relevant and experienced healthcare professionals.
    • Safety and practicality.
  • Explain that the place of care or place of death may change, for example:
    • If the child or young person and their parents or carers change their minds.
    • For clinical reasons.
    • Due to problems with service provision — if possible, services should ensure that children can be cared for at their preferred place of care and die at their preferred place of death.
  • Provide information about:
    • The various care settings (for example home, hospice or hospital care).
    • The care and support available in each setting.
    • Practical and safety issues.
  • If care at home is preferred, take into account and discuss the practical considerations, such as the possible need for:
    • Home adaptations.
    • Changes to living arrangements.
    • Equipment and support.
  • For children who are being cared for at home, services should provide (when needed):
    • Advice from a consultant in paediatric palliative care (for example by telephone) at any time (day and night).
    • Paediatric nursing care at any time (day and night).
    • Home visits by a healthcare professional from the specialist paediatric palliative care team (for example, for symptom management).
    • Practical support and equipment for interventions including oxygen, enteral nutrition, and subcutaneous and intravenous therapies. 
    • Anticipatory prescribing for children who are likely to develop symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline End of life care for infants, children and young people with life-limiting conditions: planning and management [NICE, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage the care of a child who is approaching the end of life?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Attempt resuscitation for children, unless there is a 'do not attempt resuscitation' order in place.
  • Be aware that discussing the advance care plan can be distressing for children approaching the end of life and their parents or carers, and they may:
    • Be reluctant to think about end of life care.
    • Have difficulties discussing it with the professionals or with one another.
    • Have differences of opinion about the care plan.
  • When making or reviewing the advance care plan for a child approaching the end of life, talk to the parents or carers about the care and support they can expect when the child dies — discuss their personal needs and feelings about this.
  • Think about and discuss the child's and their parents', or carers' specific support needs — review these needs regularly.
  • Be aware of the importance of talking about dying, and if appropriate discuss:
    • Whether they want and are able to talk about this.
    • Whether they or their parents or carers would like support in talking to each other about this.
  • Take into account the beliefs and values of children and their parents or carers when thinking about:
    • The possibility of treatment withdrawal.
    • Funeral arrangements and the care of the child's body after death.
  • Discuss with parents or carers what would help them, for example:
    • Important rituals.
    • Recording or preserving memories (for example with photographs, hair locks or hand prints) 
    • Plans for social media content.
  • Discuss and agree with children and their parents or carers their preferred place of care and place of death. 
  • If it is suspected that a child may die soon and they are not in their preferred place of death, think about whether rapid transfer is possible and in their best interests — discuss this with them and their parents or carers.
  • When planning rapid transfer to the preferred place of death: 
    • Review and if necessary update the advance care plan.
    • Be aware that the course of their condition may be unpredictable, and that they may die sooner or later than expected.
    • Discuss any uncertainties about the course of their condition and how this could affect their care with them and their parents or carers.
    • Ensure that relevant changes to the advance care plan are implemented.
  • Think about using a rapid transfer process to allow the child or young person to be in their preferred place of death when withdrawing life-sustaining treatments, such as ventilation.
  • Before rapid transfer, agree with the parents or carers where the child's or young person's body will be cared for after their death.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline End of life care for infants, children and young people with life-limiting conditions: planning and management [NICE, 2019].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give a child with a life-limiting condition and their parents or carers?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ensure that all parents (or carers) are given the information and opportunities for discussion that they need.
  • Provide children and their parents or carers with the information they need on: 
    • The condition and what it may mean for them.
    • Their role and participation in advance care planning. Explain that advance care planning should:
      • Help them be involved in planning their care and give them time to think about their views carefully.
      • Help them to understand the life-limiting condition and its management help to prepare for possible future difficulties or complications.
      • Support continuity of care — for example, if there are changes in the professionals involved or in the care setting (such as a hospital admission or discharge).
    • The membership of their multidisciplinary team and the responsibilities of each professional. The multidisciplinary team may include:
      • Healthcare professionals from primary, secondary or tertiary services, including specialists in the child's underlying life-limiting condition, hospice professionals and members of the specialist palliative care team.
      • Social care practitioners.
      • Educational professionals.
      • Allied health professionals (for example physiotherapists, occupational therapists, and psychological therapists).
    • The care options available, including specific treatments and the preferred Place of care and place of death.  
    • Any relevant resources or support available — for example, the charity Together for Short Lives provides information and resources for families. 
  • Be aware that:
    • Most children with life-limiting conditions and their parents or carers want to be fully informed about the condition and its management, and they value information that is:
      • Specific to the child's or young person's individual circumstances.
      • Clearly explained and understandable consistent.
      • Up-to-date.
      • Provided verbally and in writing.
    • Some children and young people and parents or carers may be anxious about receiving information about their condition.
  • Also provide information about:
    • Organ and tissue donation (if appropriate).
    • The emotional and psychological support available and how to access it.
  • Discuss the practical arrangements that will be needed after the death of their child, and provide this information in writing. This should cover matters such as:
    • The care of the body.
    • Relevant legal considerations, including.
      • The involvement of the child death overview panel. 
      • The involvement of the coroner.
      • Registration of the death.
    • Funeral arrangements.
    • Post-mortem examination (if this is to be performed).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline End of life care for infants, children and young people with life-limiting conditions: planning and management [NICE, 2019].
